author: @user-vd1tg2vt4w
comment: I don't consider renting passive income unless you have professional property management. Most people who rent don't count their time and effort needed just to make a tiny return on their massive investment. For example, you invest $599,000 to buy a second home and rent it out for $3000 a month. Let assume you are cash flow positive on the property and you make $1000 a month or $12,000 a year. What would your annualized return be? 2 percent on the entire amount. Now, you can argue that your return is much higher since you only put down $120,000 on the property. However, you are on the hook for the full $600k regardless of what the future FMV of the house is. Furthermore, people assume that their home will always appreciate in value however, this is a false assumption you can make. In the best case, you will gain some capital appreciation thanks to the central bank increasing the money supply, however, if inflation heats up, you can see your property actually start to lose money in real terms. This is because there is an inverse relationship between housing and nominal interest rates. The central bank will attempt to slow down inflation with higher interest rates and curb lending. We haven't seen inflation in a big way but we can see all the massive stimulus money that the government is pumping turn into inflation while taxes will be hiked to pay for all the COVID spending, your best choice is to look into VRI TOKEN Its more profitable.

author: @eugeniekoren4797
comment: Credit score is not something used in all countries though. In France, they determine if you are eligible to get a loan (e.g., to buy a house) based on the ratio between your salary, your expenses and your savings. Basically, if every month you 'burn' all your money, you're perceived as riskier than someone earning less but consistently making deposits to a saving account. I feel in the US people tend to buy things they don't need with money they don't have... The only times I feel one should need a credit is when buying 'big' things (house, car, etc.). Not for a TV. author: @thinkthedayaway8370
comment:
This smacks of intellectual populism, firstly marxist theory and captalism will forever be entwined as his theory was developed as a critique of capitalism; i.e. what we do with 'surplus'. They are not binary as one is based on the other.

He has condensed 400 years of complete human civic transformation to a simple cause... Capitalism. Failing to discuss or mention the 10'000 years of intellectual development and human story from the globes population that eventaully brought about the industrial revolution and global human awareness. The population growth and rapid decline from several global wars, the expansionism and wiping out of cultures (there is a reason they speak spanish in Argentina).

Free market rhetoric is fine, right up until your water suppliers are competing for prices and the cost of filtering water goes through the roof, they cut costs by dumping sewage illagally and the government can do nothing because they are lobbied by the 'free market' or train lines compete on prices killing public transport and triggering rail strikes or the health system becomes privatised and the delays of transition kill 10s of thousands of patients, or eventually the cost of your treatment becomes dictated by an algorithm maintained by the best insurance providers!
Homes become a means of wealth rather then a place to sleep and make life and meritocratic mentalities leave those who cant keep up behind.

Dont fall into the hell hole that the UK has gotten itself in, (i am british) we are the 6th largest economy in the world and yet we've never had so many homeless dying in the winter, our population has mass sickness and young people commiting suicide is the primary assumption for their death under the age of 30. Nothing works and our capital hosts some of richest individuals in the western hemisphere. We are one of the most unequal societies in Europe BECAUSE our attempts at making a nation ran by free market economics.

It all needs continuous re-assesment, the way we live. While i agree on his comments on peace, he sounds as endoctrinating as a soviet spokesman i.e. there is one system that works and here is the proof. This is not how life works we all know this, i believe we can leave a good world for our children but it takes recognising its variance first.

The rush toward capitalism as salvation is what stops me in my tracks and raises alarm bells. Some of his comments are at least forthright and clear and not filled with the trigger words of European politicians. Perhaps this is right but we in the UK have lived this game a long time and the ideas that people stand by and believe in like the NHS and working laws, health and safety ect none of them were spawned by free market capitalist or entrepreneurs. They were developed in spite of them.

We have had this rhetoric since the 1800s in the UK and if the people speaking it had their way our mothers would be working right up until they gave birth and not long after and half the population wouldnt have a vote.

18:39 Don't let anyone say ambition is immoral. If you earn money it's because you provide a superior product, better price, contributing to well-being. Do not yield to the advance of the state, the state is not the solution, the state is the problem.

SHOCKING!
He goes from ambition isn't immoral straight to If you earn money it's because you provide value. NO!

The question of whether ambition is or isn't immoral does not lie with money or the making of it! It depends on where the ambitions lead to. Do the ambitions lead to providing people with clean water in their houses while dumping the contaminates in the river killing the fish? Well, poisoning the river will lead to not only bad river water quality but also bad health for people living in it's neighborhood, and the morality is completely lost. Morality doesn't depend just on the immediate WHAT you do but it also depends on HOW you do it.

Bad economists are recognized by their failure to recognize the unintended consequences from their choices.

author: @luked2982
comment:
He says there are no market failures. It depends what he means by market failures. Some people say things like, it was a failure of the market to deal with such and such a social issue. For example, if someone is born without property in a country where education is not free, then the market will not be a successful medium to guarantee equality of opportunity (not outcome). And, of course, the problem with capitalism as a historical system is that it evolved out of the aristocratic relations of Europe, wherein a segment of the population began from year 1 with great swathes of property, and others were simultaneously disenfranchised through enclosure and sent to factories where the wages were not enough to build up any stable capital. If you continue forward through that story, democracy was only achieved at the beginning of the 20th century, after which time there were two catastrophic wars which reduced most of the continent to poverty, and they have only been climbing out of that state since. Contrary to what president Milei says, standard of living has been dropping in the West since the 1970s when calculated by purchasing power of the general population.

I did not write the above to advocate socialism or to claim that I have "debunked" the above speech, but only to point out a problem. I do not understand why many in this comment section see this speech as being radical, since it represents the ideas of the political mainstream since at least the 1980s. Every western country operates on a capitalist basis, even the social democratic ones which are not run through government planning but only differ through higher tax regimes and government spending, not in the operation of the market which are all open to competition, and there are no countries with completely unregulated markets and I doubt there ever will be because that would mean, among other things, allowing poisons into everyday products.

author: @spydude38
comment: Milei spoke of the "Life, Liberty, and Property". First penned by British Philosopher John Locke in his "Two Treatises of Government", they were used to defend the claim that all men are free and possess the inalienable right to Life, Liberty and Property independent from the laws of any specific society. This was part of the foundation Locke used to describe where the people under a social contract willingly transfer some of their fights to government in order to better enjoy the stable enjoyment of their Lives, Liberty and Property. Meaning, that under this social contract, the government exists with the consent of the governed to protect the rights of people and that governments that fail to do so can be resisted and replaced by the people. Thomas Jefferson who respected Locke replaced the word "Property" with "the pursuit of happiness" in the U.S. Declaration of Independence, which he likely borrowed from Locke again who wrote in a 1690 essay titled, "Concerning Human Understanding", "The pursuit of happiness is the foundation of Liberty". These words became part of the United States of America's Declaration of Independence.

author: @ilovejobbo
comment:
Yeah, but it's much more nuanced than just access to capital, the growth of technology and innovation, the blood sweat and tears of scientists, engineers and inventors. Not all of them were paid handsomely for their work and if you truly analyse it a lot of great ideas come when you don't have easy access to money.

Look at Nikola Tesla. Today our entire population relies on his technology, yet he was ridiculed and died poor and lonely.

I don't believe putting our faith in the largest and most successful companies blindly is also the solution to our prosperity.

Here in Australia the big 2 supermarkets have continued to raise prices in unison. And because they have accumulated so many different products and for many years undercut everyone else, there is now nowhere else to go to buy some products at sensible prices. Often bespoke places are 2-3x more expensive. Which means it's harder for individuals to change the market by voting with our wallets.

Also these supermarkets never pay their suppliers/farmers a good price, and have more and started to replace popular brands with their own brands, and they push up the price of the popular brands and then supply an inferior product at the old price of the popular brand.

Eventually all of those popular brands will stop doing business and the quality of the food will continue to degrade until there is absolutely no nutritional value left.

Why? Because someone makes more money every time they cut corners.

FUNNY. I don't think the people who have made the biggest POSITIVE impact in our world were solely motivated by money.

author: @SliceofLife7777
comment:
So, good ole Uncle Sam, get out of the way! To stimulate the economy, doing less is more. This guy from Argentina understands the American dream better than 70% of our current leadership. It is an honor to have a civilian job. You're a part of the process that turns dirt into something of value. That turns useless people into useful, more wealthy citizens.
I believe we need some government. But it should not distort the free market. Free market will build wealth. It will destroy inefficient systems, making room for leaner, hungrier, more efficient systems. It is not a government's function to bail out badly run companies.
It is not a government's function to create wealth.
It is not a government's function to do anything but enforce fair trade, and protect the nation against threats: foreign or domestic. Like invaders, or thieves and murderers.
We have the Bomb, and a means to deliver it anywhere on earth. We should take comfort in the fact that most people don't want to die at any one time. Respect a government that respects your citizenship. That trusts you. When it does not, than it deserves none from you. God bless this big blue marble, and everyone who lives on/in it.

author: @frictionhitch
comment:
Free Markets and Capitalism describe two different things.
The former is a system of trade while the latter is a system of property.
Do not speak of them together in a single breath as if it describes a single system.
Is it free markets or capitalism that is responsible for our success? and to what degree?
I would argue that it is largely free markets.
The question then becomes what degree of capitalistic property is necessary to support and maximize value within these markets?
No one in DAVOS would like the answer.
Employees having a greater share of their labors is desirable. Residents owning their own homes is desirable. Ultra wealthy brats who inherited much of their wealth is certainly not.
Often free markets are in opposition to capitalism.
I repeat do not use these two terms in a single breath as if it describes a single system.

author: @JK-nk6tl
comment:
Well I would argue that there hasn't been true capitalism in the west in 50 years.
Instead of productive capitalism, the financial system has grown to overshadow the effects of classic capitalism. The financial system act more like feudalism, growing without producing anything without contributing anything, only accumulating wealth that should otherwise circulate through real capitalism, ever gaining power by using power over other people.
The deregulation of the financial system has essentially killed the good effects of capitalism. The classic capitalism idea did not include financial systems running wild like they are, and the classic capitalism thinkers did not condone an unregulated financial system, only unregulated capitalism in the productive form.

So color me sceptic every time I hear someone praise capitalism, and then I wan't to ask ... what exactly do you mean by capitalism ?
One of the greatest and ignore problems in this world is the out of control financial system that has grown so big that capitalism, socialism, whatever ism doesn't really matter anymore - Only by addressing the problem of the financial system and the wealth accumulation by contributing nothing, can capitalism begin to work again.

The World Enslavement Forum agendas are very similar to feudalism, their member are the modern versions or Lords and normal people will be the serfs - Very much not capilism, but also no socialism (they only use socialism as a disguise).

author: @LouisMaxBlank
comment:
David Icke comments on the Mikei speech:

I heard that Milei's speech at the WEF champions freedom, so I listened. It doesn't. It seeks to move power and control from governments to corporations if you listen carefully and that‚Äôs happening anyway. What he doesn‚Äôt say is that governments and corporations are owned by the same global Cult. So either way the same cabal is in control.
The obsession with economic growth for its own sake is classic free-for-all, child-like economics, in which the strongest, most wealthy and powerful, prevail without the most basic checks and balances.
Economic growth is merely the amount of money spent on goods and services. So all the negative things that we don‚Äôt want to happen are ticked as positive by economic growth if money changes hands and profits are made.
‚ÄòFreedom‚Äô to be exploited by billionaires without redress is NOT freedom. Corporate monopolies with unchecked power is NOT freedom.
He talks about ‚Äòcapitalism‚Äô, but what he is describing in truth is cartelism.
It‚Äôs barely one-dimensional. It‚Äôs the playground. You challenge white with black and black with white while the Cult sits laughing in the shades of grey controlling both.
Milei is a child in a grown-ups‚Äô playground appearing to challenge power while handing it over to the already super-powerful. Which do you want? The ‚Äòfree‚Äô (rigged) market tyranny run riot or state-dictated communist tyranny?
Neither, thanks. I‚Äôm an adult. I want freedom and justice for all, not the few, and whether it‚Äôs Milei or Schwab the few get the spoils and the rest get the crumbs and the tyranny.

author: @Whoisemmanuel
comment:
While the speech compellingly outlines the successes of capitalism, particularly in driving economic growth and reducing global poverty, it's crucial to also recognize the system's limitations and the potential consequences of unregulated capitalism. Indeed, capitalism has been a powerful engine for innovation and wealth creation, but its unchecked form can lead to significant social and environmental issues.

One stark example is the historical exploitation of labor, epitomized by events like the Coal Wars in the United States. During the early 20th century, coal miners faced incredibly harsh working conditions, low pay, and the constant threat of injury or death. Their efforts to unionize and strike for better conditions were often met with violent responses, including interventions by the National Guard. Such incidents underscore the potential for capitalism to exploit workers when devoid of strong labor protections and regulations.

Environmental impact is another critical area of concern. The pursuit of profit in capitalist systems can, and often does, lead to environmental degradation. This is evident in the contrast between industrialized and non-industrialized cultures. For instance, the deforestation of the Amazon rainforest, driven by the capitalist motives of logging, agriculture, and mining, starkly contrasts with the sustainable practices of indigenous communities who have lived in harmony with their environment for centuries. The current climate crisis, largely fueled by the carbon emissions of industrialized nations, is a testament to the environmental cost of unregulated industrial activity.

Moreover, the issue of social inequality is an inherent risk in capitalist systems. While capitalism can generate immense wealth, this wealth is often unevenly distributed, leading to significant disparities. The growing gap between the richest and the poorest, both within countries and globally, raises questions about the social sustainability of current economic models.

While capitalism has been a driving force in creating modern prosperity, its unregulated form can lead to labor exploitation, environmental destruction, and social inequality. These challenges highlight the necessity of thoughtful regulation and the implementation of policies that ensure economic growth does not come at the expense of human welfare and environmental sustainability. The goal should be to strike a balance where the dynamism of capitalism is harnessed, but its excesses are curbed, ensuring a fair and sustainable future for all.

author: @energymarketchile
comment:
All very well, but giving carte blanche to the multinational corporations is ensuring that people will not even have reasonable jobs, that the natural resources of the countries will be devastated without leaving anything to the States (countries) from which they are extracted, and worse, the People will not have any right to defend themselves against mega-consortia.
What is needed is a State representative of the interests of the population at each country (true democracy), where the corruptive force of corporations in the political sphere is nullified, and politicians make reasonable decisions that promote the common good, and do not benefit the "elites" that Milei mentions. Milei errs in thinking that the elites are groups separate from the mega-corporations, when in reality they are the owners of the latter and all the crimes that we have seen increase to scandalous levels in these last four years are caused by mega-corporations, controlled by the elite that owns them, and that has managed to get into the pockets of every politician in every once prosperous country. In other words, he promises what we all want, but putting the shadow of the benefit of the popular doubt on delinquent businessmen.
Or someone is going to tell me that Gates, Bezos, and in Argentina, the two most powerful, are white doves... All the suffering that we have seen starting from the covid19 pandemic, the undeclared wars, the losses in pension equity funds, etc., all are the result of the excessive control that these billionaires exercise over the market, for which there is no mechanism to stop them. In effect, its abuse of monopoly power has eliminated the true creative capitalist force: small and medium-sized businesses, since large corporations have taken it upon themselves to eliminate them using politicians and their globalist 2030 agenda to make them cease to exist... True freedom will come when the excessive powers that corporations have compared to small businesses and individuals are eliminated. I'm not saying that entrepreneurship and market freedom must be eliminated, we just have to eliminate the bad elements that contaminate and destroy it from within, and put reasonable limits to prevent this to happen again.

author: @vickiwhalan4328
comment: Governments have been involved in monitoring and regulating free market capitalism in one from or another since its inception. The US may be a closer model to the one he is talking about, but other Western nations have embraced elements of collectivism within free market capitalism. Unbridled libertarianism is a myth because of the competing elements within the market. Competition between labour and capital is one example. Governments can operate as a mediating factor in this scenario and also operate as advocates and mediators  in international market disputes. Governments can also act as the warning bell. To assume that free market growth can continue without checks and balances is like a train without any brakes hurtling towards a precipice.

author: @stefashaler8340
comment: Baffling argument that leaves out such obvious facts that within our free market capitalist system, around 8 men have collected as much 'wealth' as 3.6 billion people on earth, around half the population. And that when the GDP dominates the system as it does in free market capitalism, it devours and destroys other forms of wealth: morals, spirit, safety, justice, community. For example, drug and human trafficking cartels thrive. They amp up GDPs.  Wars send GDPs through the roof. Mr. Melei also fails to mention that mega corporations are faithfully bailed out of bankruptcy by the working class. The story of businesses that can't survive on their own going out of business is a dream--a nightmare for the general public that is squeezed out of business by voracious mega-companies taking over everything, metastasizing over the globe and recently, space. It's crystal clear that elites wouldn't be proposing any kind of social adjustment if they didn't realized free market capitalism has their backs against the wall with problems the system cannot address in any effective way. They became elites in the free market system, so obviously like it but they see that it can't hold together much longer. Those who imagine material wealth is the only index of human development are prone to not seeing the catastrophes they face when the 'wealth' goes berserk.

author: @jax7585
comment:
No, hell no, Farzad. While on the surface Javier‚Äôs screed hits many of the libertarian hot buttons (many of which I agree with) it‚Äôs critical to put this speech in context. This is the speech that the pirates will make just before picking your pockets and throwing you overboard to the sharks.

Milei uses gross generalities such as comparing abortion rights to a socialist form of population control, positioning all competing political groups/philosophies as parasitic soul sucking bureaucrats compared to his vision of a benevolent and perfect meritocracy of idealistic entrepreneurs. This is reminiscent of Ayn Rand‚Äôs juvenile nonsense.

Consider the absolutely critical inflection point the 2024 election represents. We are in the early stages of the four biggest societal transformations we‚Äôve ever experienced: transportation, energy, labor and food (Hat tip: Adam Dorr‚Äôs ‚ÄúBrighter‚Äù). As we go through these transitions our society will necessarily go through some very difficult times as we are forced to abandon old ways of managing ourselves and adopt innovative --- and previously unacceptable --- new ways forward. We have two political paths to choose from this year to get us through this difficult beginning.

On the Democratic side we have a deep and wide bench of (mostly) well intentioned and capable public servants. In the last three years inflation has essentially been tamed (No, high prices aren‚Äôt inflation; they are the result of past inflation), unemployment is very low, massive investments are being made in supporting renewable energy, expansion of EVs and charging networks, fighting climate change, domestic production of microchips, basic infrastructure fixes, rebuilding of global alliances, decisive and strong support for Ukraine, Israel and NATO, and an absolute commitment to personal reproductive rights and our Constitutionally-based government. You don‚Äôt like Biden, fine; he‚Äôll be gone before, or no later than, the 2028 elections. Our democracy is designed to refresh itself through election cycles. Don‚Äôt like something? Get engaged, vote, run for office and make changes within our system.

On the other side of the aisle is the GOP, which has completely transformed into MAGA. Of which their bench is one person wide and deep. And his intended legislative positions and historical record are literally the opposite of all the evidence and positions mentioned above. And this won‚Äôt be good for long term business.

If we, in the Tesla/Elon universe, can put aside our short term frustrations with Biden‚Äôs unhinged pro-union, Mary Barra fluffing words and focus on the actions and legislation that have actually occurred the choice becomes much clearer: We can abandon our Constitutional Republic and go with the know-nothing, prima donna, narcissistic, fascist cowboy or support and force change from within the progressive, evidence-based, forward thinking Democratic party.

author: @CSHarvey
comment:
Capitalism has had a century to demonstrate how self-centered greed can magically manifest the best interests for mankind and eliminate poverty.
It has utterly failed to even pretend to do so.
Poverty isn't a bug of capitalism, it's a feature. Capitalism relies on exploitation of labor, it's core conceit being to drive down the cost of materials AND labor. That requires an exploitable labor force, one that can be kept in poverty to keep labor costs low.
The alternative is a free (as in beer) labor force - slaves or machines. And if all the work is done by machines, then who is earning the paychecks to buy the goods being made? What is the point of capitalism then?
Congratulations, you've just capitalismed so hard we've now become a post-capitalist society.

comment:
this is absurdly simplistic and inaccurate .. he is parroting adam smith capitalism .. adam smith economics is a wonderful idea but unfortunately Edison started mega corporations which dominated the so called free markets from almost the beginning of the history of capitalism ... monopoly's and the domination of profit over well being ... and more recently neo liberal economics has destroyed the lives of the majority of the world ..
capitalism in its various forms unfortunately has many inherent problems .. one of them being a built in seven year crisis .. libertarianism as a philosophy and as an economic system has many flaws ... this speech reminds me of the authoritarian and socialist simplistic arguments that become popular in times of fear and economic deprivation .. economics is a complex issue that needs new and innovative solutions that are a combination of freedom of the individual and social commons .. his remark if you earn money you are creating a benefit to society is clearly inaccurate ..are hedge fund managers creating a benefit to society? is black rock and amazon and the arms dealing corporations and the pharmaceutical companies creating a benefit to society? without regulations that are socialist in their intentions the powerful dominate the vulnerable ... his speech is an attempt to reignite the neoliberal capitalism which has destroyed the world in the last forty years .. economics and social organisations are not as simple as capitalism versus socialism .. he sounds like a child parroting cia talking points

author: @wincoffin7985
comment: So I'm just a simple John Doe (and huge Tesla fan & investor, Farzad fan too) who has never studied economics in depth, but I have a deep appreciation and awe for nature, ecosystems, and humanity's dependence on them.  I'm almost convinced that libertarianism has tremendous power to improve all our lives and reduce poverty as the speaker says.... but I've never heard how it takes environmental protection into account.  I think libertarian theory needs to be somehow expanded to include environmental health (including species diversity, rich ecosystems, natural abundance, clean air, etc. etc.).  If every entrepreneur is allowed free reign to exploit natural resources, well, yes, poverty may reduce, per capita income may rise, all may seem good -- until our air becomes unbreathable, our lands become agriculturally diminished, our fisheries dwindle, our climate becomes unlivable, etc. etc.  This MUST be taken into account, or we'll all hit a wall -- the poor and the rich alike.

I like socialism in the sense that if the system can create billionaires and soon trillionaires, it makes sense that every human on earth should have housing, internet access, food, clothing, Healthcare, and education as rights.

Right now there are only a few players making the decisions and dictating policy. Whenever a small minority is making decisions for the majority, it is very seldom if at all that these decisions will benefit the masses....

author: @joekerr8037
comment:
A leader who is so obsessed with dogmas and political ideology will fk up his country even more.

China gave up their political ideologies to embrace "socialism with Chinese characteristics" under Deng.
The Chinese leaders are pragmatists and not ideologues.
The Singaporean leaders are the same.

"We were not ideologues. We did not believe in theories as such. A theory is an attractive proposition intellectually. What we faced was a real problem of human beings looking for work, to be paid, to buy their food, their clothes, their homes, and to bring their children up‚Ä¶I had read the theories and maybe half believed in them.

But we were sufficiently practical and pragmatic enough not to be cluttered up and inhibited by theories. If a thing works, let us work it, and that eventually evolved into the kind of economy that we have today. Our test was: does it work? Does it bring benefits to the people?‚Ä¶The prevailing theory then was that multinationals were exploiters of cheap labor and cheap raw materials and would suck a country dry‚Ä¶Nobody else wanted to exploit the labor. So why not, if they want to exploit our labor? They are welcome to it‚Ä¶. We were learning how to do a job from them, which we would never have learnt‚Ä¶ We were part of the process that disproved the theory of the development economics school, that this was exploitation. We were in no position to be fussy about high-minded principles."
- Lee Kuan Yew

author: @piscesman54
comment:
There are a few troubling things about Milei that most people outside of Argentina are not aware of. To begin with, he's a staunch supporter of Israel, a murderous, oppressive, racist State, currently executing one of the most horrific genocides in modern history. So one has to wonder how that jives with the libertarian ideas he so boldly proclaims. He's also closely linked to and sponsored by the Jewish Orthodox Jabad-Lubavitch organization that was recently in the news for some serious incidents involving secret tunnels at its headquarters in New York, with some very bizarre ramifications. In fact, he traveled there and visited said headquarters less than a month back.
It's fairly easy to make bold speeches decrying collectivism. Unfortunately, actions speak louder than words. Milei is not what he's made himself out to be. He recently issued what has been termed as a mega-decree, which is virtually tantamount to a full-fledged constitutional reform that would give the Executive full powers to do pretty much whatever it wants. This decree has yet to go through Congress, which is under the opposition‚Äôs control, but in Argentina that‚Äôs nothing that can‚Äôt be easily fixed with a few bribes. However, he might have to make some concessions in order to allow the opposition to save face. The decree includes one obscure article whereby the president is given the power to 'invite' foreign military forces to conduct operations on Argentinean territory. No mention is made of what forces those might be, what the actual scope of their operations would be, or how long they would be allowed to operate on Argentinean soil. So, again, how is that consistent with less obtrusive governance and individual freedom, not to mention that it raises some serious questions about the man's allegiance. Bear in mind that Argentina has the third largest Jewish community in the world, and Patagonia was one of the locations considered by early Zionist leaders for the establishment of the State of Israel. Today, it stands virtually defenseless, as Argentina's military has been scaled down to operational unviability. To make matters worse, it is very scarcely populated.
So please, dig deeper, question, research. Don't be fooled by eloquent speeches. Investigate what goes on in back rooms behind closed doors.

author: @chrisperkins7331
comment: I am sure many will not agree with my comment but I will type it anyway. A free market economy has created a wealth disparity that is heading us back to the wealth structure of the eighteenth century, where most people were effectively slaves for the landed gentry. Just because GDP grows does not mean most of us are better off than our parents. The middle class grew out of the end of WW2, as home ownership (which is the cornerstone of being middle class) and peeked around 20 years ago. Modern day poverty always seems to be measured in monitory terms, but there are other ways to measure poverty. Loneliness, bad health, no future prospects to name a few which are becoming endemic in much of the world. The amount of money now in circulation is now around 280 T$, which is why GDP increases. But as a planet we are dying and simply increasing the speed that money moves around the planet will not bring the end of poverty for the majority.

author: @colingenge9999
comment:
Shocked that so many like this guy without drilling down into details. He mentions the same ideas repeatedly without adding detail as to how this could be done.

Read Ayn Rand, Atlas Shrugged‚Ä¶ you‚Äôll see his idea represented there in this 100 year old book. Nothing new.

Idolizing the free market and chastising ‚Äúcollectivistic Socialism‚Äù which is a failed experiment from the 1920s that does not represent any existing government form today.

Chastising regulation without explaining who could trust that an aircraft that hasn‚Äôt met the many thousands of compliances in order to be airworthy. I would not want to get on an Argentinian aircraft that did not meet up-to-date, certifications and comply with the regulations of international bodies.

Look at the crap buildings in Turkey, where a minor earthquake caused tens of thousands of deaths because inspectors were bribed and regulations were not followed.

Fracking in the US is bad enough where we won‚Äôt have to pay the price of the toxification of groundwater in many States for decades to come but imagine this on a larger scale with virtually, all the groundwater and a lot of the surface water turned toxic.

No regulations; isn‚Äôt that great! But we can‚Äôt drink the water, we can‚Äôt breathe the air, and the food in our supermarket is so laced with toxins that all of a sudden the health of our citizens drop off, but we fired all the bureaucrats, so we can‚Äôt do anything about it. We have succeeded in creating a bunch of wealthy people who been stashing their cash in Switzerland then start thinking they‚Äôve done wonderful things when all they‚Äôve done is sold their country out.

Doesn‚Äôt sound like this guy has thought any of this stuff through. Past history has told us that these idealized notions don‚Äôt work. Is this guy smart enough to make changes on the fly? I kind of doubt that‚Äôs the case since he doesn‚Äôt really have much of the basics down. Just a bunch of idealized nonsense.

author: @dontfollowme4057
comment: I hung in there for 6 mins. This speech was so lacking in nuance that it was basically free-market rhetoric. A mixed free-market and socially democratic system has been proven to be superior to a purely free-market based economy. The countries that have implemented it well with a light and strong touch in certain areas have thrived, and are some of the wealthiest economies in history. This video wastes 19:07 seconds of your time with a bad faith argument. I decided to watch the whole thing in the end. Companies cannot govern themselves without the guard rails of sometimes extensive regulation. They have proven time and time again that they will endanger the entire world economy by making the riskiest and craziest bets while experimenting on the entire world with said schemes. And then with these failures they then run to the government to bail them out at the expense of the tax payer. He mentions subsidies which the capitalist always will take and often lobby for, killing the so-called free-market which relies on true competition to weed out superfluous businesses and industries..

author: @vietnameseloempia
comment:
Wealth expressed in GDP is far from a perfect indicator of the wellbeing of humans.

Too many people get sick and unhealthy from sitting in an office all day making toxic products that overwhelm the planet with waste and then are forced to spend all the money they earned by sacrificing their life and health on overpriced doctors and pharmaceutical companies who don't focus on making you healthy but on controlling your symptoms by keeping you just sick enough to keep buying medicines and treatment.

All of these things are great for GDP 'amazing, look at all that money being made and spent!' but very bad for real well-being.

Don't get me wrong, I don't say that capitalism is bad or that there is something else much better, but it's clear as daylight that capitalism alone is not enough for real well-being.

Having the market regulators necessary to mitigate (and unfortunately they can only mitigate, not eliminate) the effects of inevitable market failures leading to rampant pollution (negative externalities), doesn't fall out of the sky just like market products and services don't. You need to fund these collectively.

I'm not arguing that socialism and very high taxes are better, but it is obviously a matter of striking a balance between competing values and interests and hopefully we can get as close as possible to an optimal balance. Arguing blindly for only one side of the spectrum, will not bring an optimal balance.

.
.
.
.

.
.
.

.
.

.
.

author: @thedownwardmachine
comment:
While he is correct about a lot here, in terms of the benefits of capitalism, there is a lot wrong here as well that he ignores. I will focus on this.

Capitalism, like all things, is not perfect, and he does not talk about its problems. One of the biggest is cost externalities, in which people not party to a transaction bear a cost. This sounds academic, but it manifests, for example, as mine owners dumping tailings into a river. Drinking water and fishing -- each being forms of natural wealth -- are depleted to save money for the mine owners, perhaps less than is non-consensually extracted from the river users. Protecting against cost externalities is a prime function of governments.

He also talks about how government should not provide services but instead let services be handled by businesses, since they are more efficient. One problem with this is, what does efficiency look like for a government entity? Take police, for example -- should they make a certain number of arrests to fulfill quotas? Should we have only private police? If you cannot afford private police, do you not get protection or justice? Governments (in democracies) take actions on behalf of citizens as demanded, and all are expected to pay up as appropriate for their economic status.

He speaks of taxes as a form of coercion. This is true, people with guns will lock you in a cage if you do not pay up. But where is a state without taxation? There are failed states, but these are run by warlords who extract tribute for protection -- taxes by another name. Taxes will ultimately be paid, and in exchange you (ought to) get civilization.

But let's say we magically get rid of taxes, and everyone lives without government. Then some people and together and start doing crime. What then? You will need to form you own autodefense group, complete with obligatory contributions in time, material, and money -- taxes again!

If socialists gain support criticizing capitalism, it's because they have a point -- many have their wants satisfied while many have their needs neglected. This is a problem libertarians do not acknowledge, capitalism's price signals do not distinguish between needs and wants: a rich person can buy all the water for their pool while the impoverished go thirsty.

He talks about capitalism being the greatest mechanism for wealth creation that the world has ever seen, and he talks about ever increasing GDP-per-capita figures, but behind this hides the distribution of that wealth. Who actually has it? Do those without it have enough to survive, to thrive, to challenge the wealthy with better business offerings? An enormous amount of wealth accumulated is coercive in its own right, and balanced only by the collective will of the people -- that is, the rule of law under a democratic government.

Milei is an extremist borne of extreme circumstances. Extremists are often have a point but are blinded to the flaws of their viewpoint. Just as the communists denigrated humanity for the promise of a utopia, Milei is so repelled by government that he cannot see its purpose.

I hope that he delivers the shock that Argentina needs to become peaceful and prosperous. Hopefully his corrections will not cause so many problems that it gives life to an extremist opposition.

comment: Boring, but dangerous speech.  Yes, we all know what Capitalism is, and that Communism does not work.  However, to suggest that Capitalism can't be moderated with 'social justice' is just a Far Right wolf cry, and should be avoided just as much as Far Left calls to full socialism/communism.  Yes, GDP is growing more than ever now- however, the middle class is also SHRINKING now and their economic growth for the past 50 years has been almost flat.  You have to address these inequalities or the door opens for extremism.  Keep in mind 'pure capitalism' drove monopolies and extremely poor working conditions for much of the 19th and early 20th centuries.  Putting into place so-called Social Justice programs to mitigate these conditions enabled GDP growth across economic sectors- it was these changes, in addition to GDP growth, that shrunk poverty.
